Variation Example: A crane (stork) proposes to a heron. She refuses him. After some thought she goes to the crane, but he sends her away. Then he changes his mind & goes to the heron again, but is refused, etc.
Two sparrows are starving. One flies away to look for food & finds some cherries. He eats his fill & flies back with some for his companion, but finds he is already dead.

Classifications: Raven Drowns His Young Who Promise to Aid Him When He Becomes Old
Variation Example: He saves only the one who admits that he will not carry the old bird because he will have to carry his own young.

Classifications: The Tame Bird & the Wild Bird
Variation Example: A tame bird advises the wild bird to look about him. The wild bird is shot.
When a hunter bends his bow, one bird (fish, deer) flies away. The other one remains & is shot.

Classifications: Each Mother Likes Her Own Children Best
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A partridge asks an owl (raven) to take some food to its child at school. The owl wants to know how to recognize the child & the partridge answers that its child is the most beautiful. But the owl considers its own child as most beautiful & gives it the food. (2) A snipe asks an eagle (hawk, wolf, sportsman) to spare its young, saying that they are easily recognized as the prettiest in the forest. The eagle eats only the ugliest little birds it can find. They are the young snipes.

A man inadvertently runs over a dog, the friend of a sparrow. The sparrow takes vengeance & annoys the man. He tries to kill it but, in so doing, he kills his horse or destroys his cargo. The man catches the bird & devours it alive. When the bird looks out from his backside or his mouth, his wife tries to kill it. Instead, she hurts or kills her husband.

An elephant tramples a lark’s nest. The lark’s friends take revenge. The frog croaks & causes the elephant to fall into a dry pool, the crow pecks out the elephant’s eyes, & the bees sting the elephant to death.
The fish have a race, & the smaller one wins. The perch hangs on to the tail of the salmon & is the winner.

The fish have a race to elect their king. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The flounder cries out in jealousy because the herring is winning. (2) The flounder makes a discourteous remark to God. It is punished by having its mouth made crooked.
The little fish slip through the mesh; the big ones are caught.
It's a race between two animals.

In a race between a fast animal (hare) & a slow animal (tortoise, toad), the fast animal sleeps on the road because it thinks it has plenty of time. The slow animal is able to pass it & wins the race by its endurance.

Classifications: The Race of the Fox & the Crayfish
Variation Example: The crayfish (crab, frog, toad, tick, chameleon) hangs on to the fox’s tail & wins. In some Asian variants the animals have a jumping contest. The smaller animal hangs on to the bigger & wins.

The slower animal outwits the faster. The hedgehog (tortoise, mussel, snail) asks a relative (his wife) to wait at the other end of the race course or several relatives are placed along the course. The rabbit (fox, jackal) runs from one end to the other until he is completely exhausted.
The snail wins the race because the frog cannot pass a gate on the road & has to wait. The snail crawls over it.

Classifications: Crab Walks Backwards: Learned from his Parents
Variation Example: The father (mother) of a crab wants to oblige its child to walk straight. The child answers that the parent should walk straight first.

When the frogs (ants) ask God (Jupiter) for a king, he throws a log into the water. They are unhappy. God sends a crane (stork, snake) to be the king & it eats up the frogs. They regret that they were not satisfied with their first king.

Classifications: Frog Tries in Vain to be as Big as an Ox
Variation Example: He puffs himself up until he bursts.
A frog (toad) ties its feet to those of a mouse in order to cross a lake (marsh). On the way, the frog almost drowns the mouse. A falcon carries them off & eats them both.

Classifications: Frog Persists in Living in Puddle on Road
Variation Example: A frog disregards the advice of another frog to move with him to a lake. He is run over.

Classifications: Frogs Decide Not to Jump in Well
Variation Example: When their spring dries up, the frogs consider jumping into a well. They decide that the well may also dry up & they would be unable to get out.

Classifications: Snake Trying to Surround Crab Refuses to Straighten Himself
Variation Example: A snake & a crab want to live together, but the snake surrounds the crab too closely. The crab objects & kills it. Then the snake straightens itself out & the crab thinks, they can be friends.

Classifications: The Ant Carries a Load as Large as Himself
Variation Example: An ant & a raven (bear) have a contest to see if they can each carry a load as large as themselves up into a tree. The ant wins. Often combined with an etiological explanation (why the raven lays its eggs in March, why the bear eats ants).

During the summer, an ant collects food for the winter while a cricket (grasshopper) sings. In the winter, the cricket asks for food from the ant, but it refuses to help & advises the cricket to dance.

This type exists chiefly in four different forms: (1) Gnats want to kill a horse. When it rolls over, they think they have thrown him. (2) Some gnats apologize for landing on bull’s horns. But the bull did not feel their weight. (3) Gnats defeat a lion but are killed in a spider web. (4) A man cannot chase a buffalo away from a mud hole. A gnat succeeds.

The two insects (often an insect & an illness, or two illnesses like fever or gout, also with spider & mucus or mucus & excrement) meet & complain about their lives. The flea is unhappy in the country (with poor people) & the fly in the city (with rich people), so they switch places & are content.

A flea & a fly talk about their lives. The flea is hunchbacked because he crawls under rags all night long on the sleeping man. The fly has swollen eyes because he laughs so much over man’s unsuccessful efforts to catch him.
A louse invites a flea to spend the night. The flea bites a sleeping person & jumps away. The sleeper searches his bed, finds the louse, & kills it. Sometimes the flea & the bedbugs are killed too.

Classifications: The Louse & the Flea Spend the Night in a woman's backside & vagina
Variation Example: The next morning they tell each other what happened to them. The woman had sexual intercourse.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A spider invites a fly (wasp) to rest on her “curtain”. But it is really her web & she eats the fly. (2) A spider catches many flies & releases one of them so that it can tell the others that the spider is harmless. But when more insects come to the spider’s web, the spider eats them.
Fly, mouse, hare, fox, & wolf gather in a mit-ten (skull). A bear sits down on the mitten & crushes all of them.

Classifications: The Woman Laughs at the Silkworm
Variation Example: The Spider Laughs at the Silkworm for working so slowly. The silk-worm replies that his work is valuable, whereas that of the spider is worthless.

Classifications: The Dungbeetle Keeps Destroying Eagle's eggs
Variation Example: Finally, the eagle flies up into the sky & lays the eggs on Zeus’s lap. The dungbeetle causes Zeus to shake his apron & break the eggs.
A child shares its milk with a snake. When the mother sees this, she fears for her child & kills the snake. Soon the child becomes ill & dies.

A snake is fed milk & brings luck (money) to a man (household). Some one kills (injures) the snake (its young) by mistake (from greed) & thereafter the snake brings bad luck. Often the man tries to conciliate the snake (bird). It refuses because the pain it suffered cannot be forgiven.

Classifications: The Adder Poisons the Children's Food
Variation Example: Because their mother has thrown away her eggs. The mother puts the eggs back. The adder up sets the pot with the poisoned food.

Classifications: Snake Stays in the Man's Stomach
Variation Example: A farmer sleeps under a tree & a snake is about to crawl into his mouth. A nut drops from the tree & wakens the farmer, who kills the snake & eats the nut.

Classifications: The Snake Stays in the Man's Stomach
Variation Example: A man (woman) sleeps under a tree with his mouth open. A snake crawls unnoticed into his body, & he feels sick.

Classifications: Snake Tries to Bite on a File
Variation Example: A snake (weasel) bites a sharp metal file & injures its mouth, but the animal thinks that the file shed the blood.
